content.rendered: A practical way to carry out your Critical Success Factors is to prioritize. Identify what you think will be the most essential parts of your work, and schedule them each day. Then plan your meetings and tasks according to this simple schedule. REMEMBER—make sure to protect time with your family and other important priorities.

If you want to increase the number of people in your downline, Critical Success Factors might include…

  • finding a new source of leads,
  • making new contacts,
  • finding a different way to encourage new people,
  • training and communicating more effectively with your downline, or
  • discovering better ways of helping people transition from casual builder to committed leader, etc.

content.rendered: Sarah just enrolled. She was very excited about the products and loved to use them herself, but because she was new, she was unsure how to get started building. She realized the first thing she needed to do was to give herself a direction, something to aim for. She talked with other consultants to get a better idea of a healthy pace she could work at to build and share. She decided that, to start with, her rank goals would be to hit a new rank every two months. Using these outcomes, she worked backward to create a daily, weekly, and monthly routine necessary to achieve her selected outcomes of reaching needed volume and her rank goals. Following a routine directly targeting a specific outcome motivated Sarah to work effectively and feel successful each time she hit rank.

content.rendered: In the idea-generation stage, generally accept everybody’s ideas. A constructive way of responding to ideas that are not possible/allowed/productive is to say something like, “Good idea,” and then give a reason that makes the idea impractical (company policy, government regulation, etc.) “But company policy doesn’t allow us to do that/use that terminology.” Acknowledge your team’s suggestions and participation, and express appreciation.

content.rendered: When questioning successes or shortcomings, take a constructive approach. If a class goes poorly, for example, blaming is not constructive. If a new builder makes promises but doesn’t follow through, blaming does not motivate. Finding solutions does! If there is a problem, formulate a plan and commit to do better. For example, collaborate to identify what worked well in the class and what did not go well. Discuss solutions, and implement them in the next class. These are the traits of a successful entrepreneur and leader!

content.rendered:
Assume the Sale
A great way to increase sales or “sharing” of product is to simply assume the sale is going to happen. It is a very low-pressure technique for you and your customers. You know the products are awesome and they will help people, so simply guide them through the buying process. Even if people are skeptical, your confidence can be contagious and start to shift people from casual learner to buyer.

NOTE: Don’t assume too much too fast. Occasionally gauge interest and understanding by asking questions (e.g., “How do you see yourself using these products?”)

• “Sharing products is as simple as teaching classes like I did tonight. Others simply share with friends and family and in one-on-one situations with people who are looking for help—just like you would share a favorite recipe or a tip to remove stubborn stains. And we all do that.”
  • “You can share at any level you want, based on your goals. Some people decide to share to the extent that the products they want are paid for. People share to pay for groceries, their mortgage, school tuition, or a kid’s dance class or activities, help with retirement, pay down debts, or for fun like traveling or going on vacation.”
  • “Our team has a strong support system for any level you want to participate.”

And second, people love the products so much, they start sharing them with family and friends. Eventually, they want to know what the benefits are when they share. So I’ll take a couple minutes to explain that process.”

content.rendered:
You have an opportunity to build trust here. The loyalty program is great for people who use a lot of the product, but it may not be for everybody. Even though it benefits you, put the needs of others first by explaining that the loyalty program is ideal for people who use the products frequently but perhaps not for those who use them occasionally.

The reward for you, whether they sign up or not, is that you show you have integrity, which the world needs more of, but if these people trust you, they are more likely to be great sources of referrals or additional classes for you. Think long term. Would you rather have one more loyalty program enrollment or have integrity and additional classes?

excerpt.rendered:
You have an opportunity to build trust here. The loyalty program is great for people who use a lot of the product, but it may not be for everybody. Even though it benefits you, put the needs of others first by explaining that the loyalty program is ideal for people who use the products frequently …

Continue reading “LM: Loyalty”

content.rendered:
Have helpful charts or brochures available for individuals who show more interest, but do not refer to them with the group. If the class has run long or the timing does not feel right to introduce loyalty programs, tell individuals you will explain the benefits of the loyalty program at their first follow up.

  • Define it simply.
    “The loyalty program helps you to be eligible for additional discounts or credit toward products when you share products with people.”
  • Explain advantages and uses.
    • “The loyalty program is for those who use the products frequently or want a greater selection and want to replace them on a regular basis. The loyalty program makes this more affordable.”
    • “The loyalty program makes you eligible for free products, depending on what you order.”
    • “Enrolling in the loyalty program is required if you want to be an active consultant.”

Have helpful charts or brochures available for individuals who show more interest, but do not refer to them with the group. content.rendered: Mindset Tip: If you feel stuck, you can create momentum and excitement by sharing the experiences of people you personally know who have started with these kits. Sharing these experiences replaces awkwardness with positive thoughts, and this will be apparent in your presentation. Optimism and excitement are contagious.

content.rendered: Confidence comes when you believe in something but expand your abilities and your mindset by being open to new possibilities. EXAMPLE: You believe in the $550 kit because that’s what you started with, but be open to believing in the value of lower-priced kits and even higher-priced kits. Improve your ability to read your audience to determine which kit or product benefits them the most. Improve your confidence by increasing your product knowledge and being able to explain different benefits of different kits. Confidence, being open-minded, reading people, and product expertise are all leadership skills you can develop yourself and teach to your builders to increase sales.

content.rendered:
Example: Present $150 kit versus similar $275 kit OR $275 kit versus a $550 kit. Point out benefits of the different kits:

  • “These two kits include the same products but in different sizes. The larger kit is a better value and will last you a lot longer. You will have to replace the smaller size sooner, but it does cost less up front.”
  • “If you have multiple health goals, this kit is a great option because it provides so many options, and it is twice the value.”
  • “Which kit do you feel is the best fit for you?” or “If you were to get started today, which kit would you choose?”

Trusting each other is necessary for true collaboration to exist, and true collaboration is necessary for the highest level of performance.

content.rendered: Create teamwork so the power of leadership is shared with those who are led. People who work together influence each other. The most positive form of influence exists when the power of leadership is shared with people rather than retained by one or two. Coercion, threat, or any other form of excessive individual control may temporarily move people to act, but if power is not shared, the willingness to achieve and the overall health of the team is diminished. Share leadership by adopting others’ ideas when appropriate.

content.rendered:
Karen was excited about a new and very motivated builder she enrolled. She followed the steps and frequently communicated with this new builder to keep her working and to offer support. But after some time, the builder voiced her dissatisfaction with Karen and requested a change to a different team leader. Karen was confused because she was simply following the model that was taught to her.

What Karen failed to discover soon enough was that this new builder did not like the frequent, even daily, contact. Because of a lack of trust and communication, the builder did not mention this dissatisfaction, nor did Karen establish an interpersonal relationship with the builder to identify what level of follow up and communication the builder preferred. Karen lost a great builder because she didn’t know how to create trust.

Then he improved his Operational Processes by ordering the right amount of products in advance so he was always prepared and ready to share.

content.rendered:
Think about your method or the process you use to make changes and improve your performance.

Successful leaders observe people, understand the personality traits of those they observe, and know which feelings will motivate. Here’s what you can do:

  • Identify the different talents of your team members, and find ways to helpfully use these abilities to improve your team’s overall performance.
  • Motivate your team by paying attention to and recognizing their efforts and the new skills they learn.
  • Create excitement by acknowledging progress and new results.

You begin to innovate when you combine efforts to change with the existing abilities of your team members.

content.rendered:
You might think that trying to do something better will be easy to do because everyone will recognize the need for it. But innovating to improve and achieve something better can be difficult for some people. This is because it involves making changes, and it’s always easier to do what is familiar. There are three main types of responses to change and innovation:

  1. People talk about supporting it but then don’t.
  2. People openly resist innovation because change is difficult.
  3. People support innovation and invest in it.

Taking on new or different tasks may create some anxiety and discomfort. This is why proposed changes are often met with resistance and defensiveness. The problem is, growth and improvement are the results of change. Usually they are the results of people doing something differently and better. So the solution is to help your team improve by learning how to build their capacity so change comes more easily.
